text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm live tandoori lamb that's right if
you're a fan of lamb man are you going
to enjoy this but even if you're not
keep watching because this amazing
marinade is also great on chicken and
pork and even beef and I know the cow is
sacred in India but for me what better
way to celebrate an animal's life than
by eating it tandoori style once it's
gone but anyway that's a moot point
since we are using lamb or should I say
moved point but anyway let's go ahead
and get started with the first step
which is the aforementioned amazing
marinade and we'll begin with some
yogurt and because of muscle memory I
automatically grab the Greek style
yogurt which is strained and much
thicker than regular yogurt and while
both styles are going to work this stuff
is so much thicker it is a little more
difficult to work with so if I was you I
would just get the regular stuff but
either way to that we will add some
freshly squeezed lemon juice as well as
some grated or very very very finely
minced onions we will also do some
finely crushed garlic as well as some
freshly grated ginger root and then as
far as the spices go we're definitely
gonna want some garm masala which you
will find in the spice aisle of your
finer stores but if you can I'm going to
tell you how to make your own on the
blog and then to that let's go ahead and
add some ground cumin as well as let's
toss in a spoon of paprika and while
we're adding red pepper let's also add a
little or a lot of cayenne and the last
but not least we will finish up with a
little bit of tumeric which apparently
if you eat enough of you live to like
100 years old which I'm not exactly sure
is a good thing but that's a subject for
another video but anyway once all that's
together what we'll do is take a whisk
and give that a mix and as soon as
that's all combined it's ready to use
and yes because I did use that Greek
style yogurt mine's going to be really
thick which is fine but as I mentioned
if you use a regular stuff this is going
to be a little thinner and easier to
work with
not to mention probably much more
attractive but anyway we'll go ahead and
give that a mix and simply set that
aside while we prep our lamb and while
there are many cuts that will work
nicely here I'm going to go with what I
think is a very underused cut of lamb
the top sirloin and as you can see
they're pretty much all meat except
there is this one little flap that has a
piece of silver skin
attached so what we'll do is cut that
off right where it naturally separates
and then do the old stick the knife
under the silver skin and trim it off
and other than that little bit of basic
butchery we are pretty much ready to cut
this up into chunks and while I trim
that off I should mention the reason I
like to top sirloin this is going to be
very similar to using Lego lamb but I
find it's less expensive and doesn't
have as much connective tissue but if
you can't find it the leg will work as
would shoulder which is always nice on
the grill
but anyway once we remove those flaps
and trimmed off the silver skin I like
to cut the remaining clot in half and
then we'll cut it across like this and
do whatever size pieces we want which of
course the exact size will be up to you
you guys are after all the Daft Punk's
of your chunks but be careful not to
make them too small all right we don't
want the inside cooking through before
the outside has time you get a little
bit of color so I'm going to go ahead
and chunk that up as shown at which
point we can toss that into our marinade
and then besides the meat I'm also going
to add the salt here which I could add
it to the marinade but it really doesn't
matter as long as we added in at some
point and then we'll go ahead and mix
this up until we're very confident every
single one of those chunks is evenly
coated oh by the way regarding the salt
some recipes call for salting the meat
first letting that sit for a while and
then adding it to the marinade which
probably is a little more effective but
since I'm going to leave this overnight
I really don't notice a big difference
but anyway we'll go ahead and combine
all that together thoughtfully and
thoroughly at which point we can sort of
scrape everything down and clean up the
sides of the bowl before topping it with
plastic and transferring it into the
fridge for an overnight marinade which
is my preference but if time management
is not your thing you can let this go
for as little as four hours and it will
still come out pretty nice but anyway
regardless of how long we let it
marinade we'll go ahead and impel it on
some metal skiers and as I'm grabbing
these chunks I'm kind of wiping off most
of the marinade but don't worry about
getting it all we're going to give it a
little wipe later and as you're doing
this I want you to concentrate on two
things first and most importantly do not
stab your hand or fingers and secondly
do not push these too tightly together
all right they should just barely be
touching and not totally smoosh together
okay otherwise you're robbing yourself a
surface area
and as I taught you a long time ago
surface area equals flavor and then what
we'll do once at set is take a paper
towel or two and try to wipe off most of
the excess marinade from the meat and
the plate all right a little bits okay
but we generally don't want to put super
wet things on a grill so that's looking
good and then a couple last things
before we head outside I'm going to
drizzle over a little bit of vegetable
oil and we'll sort of brush that all
over and then last but not least if we
want and I did I'm going to give it one
more little sprinkling of salt on all
sides and that's it our tandoori lamb is
ready for the grill so I'm going to go
ahead and set that down over some
beautiful glowing coals okay remember we
always wait for the flames go away and
what we'll do is grill these for about
10 to 15 minutes depending on the size
of your chunks or until that meats
somewhere between medium-rare and medium
and for this recipe in most recipes
where I use a yogurt marinade I don't
want to cook over extremely high heat
right I would describe this as kind of
medium to medium-high and my usual game
plan is to cook that for about five
minutes aside and then I'll just start
randomly turning them around until I'm
happy
and I find this kind of thing too small
to use a thermometer so I just go until
they kind of spring back to the touch
okay so that felt a little bit rare and
by rare I mean wishy so I gave it a
couple more minutes and by the way to
take the pressure off if you overcook
this a little bit because of this
marinade it's still going to be
beautifully juicy and flavorful so try
to relax the fact for something like
this I would always err on the side of a
minute too long
versus a minute undercooked but anyway
I'm sure you'll figure it out
and once I determine mine was done I
went ahead and pulled it off the grill
and headed inside where I thought it
came out looking very nice although the
appearance was outdone by the aroma I
mean this stuff just smells incredible
and then as far as service goes I like
to do these on top of some grilled red
onions maybe with some freakishly small
lemon wedges and I finished up with some
freshly chopped cilantro or coriander as
they would call it on that British
baking show and that's it what I
personally consider tandoori lamb is
done so let me go ahead and unscrew a
piece and go in for a taste and while
I'm not exactly sure how close is going
to be to the lamb tandoori at your
favorite Indian restaurant I can tell
you it's going to be very moist and
extremely flavorful and as you can see
that meat stay nice and pink although
like I said and I probably shouldn't
even tell you this but even if you cook
this meeting well or even a little past
that you are still going to get a
fantastic product speaking of which if
you make some nice little small but
slightly thicker Lebanese mountain
breads those topped with some cilantro
chutney and topped that with two or
three chunks of meat and some grilled
onions and finish it with some lemon and
cilantro you will have created the
world's first lamb tandoori slider well
actually I guess technically I did but
you know what you guys go ahead and take
the credit I got the job but anyway that
was his incredibly delicious as it
looked I mean I could have eaten like
four of these and possibly did but
anyway that's it my take on tandoori
lamb whether you end up using lamb like
we did here or try with chicken or pork
or sacred cow although you know what
forget to be there could be bad karma
but regardless of what meat uses
delicious marinade for I really do hope
you give it a try soon so head over to
food which is calm for all the
ingredient amounts our moral as usual
and is all we enjoy
